Hi Joe, 

> It's also worth noting that in NUnit, for example, test case 
> instances are pooled, so initializing in the constructor does 
> not behave as you might expect. There's nothing in the 
> contract of the JUnit test case that guarantees that 
> instances are not pooled, so JUnit 5.0, for example, could 
> decide to pool instances of test case. At that point, you'd 
> have to change your code.

Since you mentioned NUnit, I'd like to clarify. NUnit simply creates one
instance of the test class for use in all tests. I associate the term
"pooling" with taking objects out of and returning them to a pool of some
kind. We do nothing like that.

The distinction between guaranteed behavior and incidental behavior is a
really important one for any test framework. In NUnit, the SetUp versus
constructor question doesn't arise, but there's an equivalent one about
TestFixtureSetUp versus constructor that comes up all the time.

Charlie
